contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox Geopolitical organization |name = Cairns Group |linking_name = Cairns Group |symbol_type = |image_symbol = |symbol_width = 150px |image_map = Cairns Group.PNG |map_caption = Cairns Group countries in light blue |org_type = Agricultural exporting countries |membership_type = Members |membership = {{Collapsible list | title = 19 Countries |{{flag|Argentina}} |{{flag|Australia}} |{{flag|Bolivia}} |{{flag|Brazil}} |{{flag|Canada}} |{{flag|Chile}} |{{flag|Colombia}} |{{flag|Costa Rica}} |{{flag|Guatemala}} |{{flag|Indonesia}} |{{flag|Malaysia}} |{{flag|New Zealand}} |{{flag|Pakistan}} |{{flag|Paraguay}} |{{flag|Peru}} |{{flag|Philippines}} |{{flag|South Africa}} |{{flag|Thailand}} |{{flag|Uruguay}}}} |admin_center_type = |admin_center = |leader_title1 = |leader_name1 = |leader_title2 = |leader_name2 = |established = |official_website = }} The '''Cairns Group''' is an interest group of 19 agricultural exporting countries, composed of [[Argentina]], [[Australia]], [[Bolivia]], [[Brazil]], [[Canada]], [[Chile]], [[Colombia]], [[Costa Rica]], [[Guatemala]], [[Indonesia]], [[Malaysia]], [[New Zealand]], [[Pakistan]], [[Paraguay]], [[Peru]], the [[Philippines]], [[South Africa]], [[Thailand]], and [[Uruguay]]. ==History and objectives== The Group takes its name from the Australian city of [[Cairns]], where its inaugural meeting took place in 1986. The Australian Government led the formation of the group, though some of the South East Asian countries had been working together on agricultural trade through [[ASEAN]]. The move to form the group was largely a response to the spiralling trade subsidies of the [[European Union]]'s [[Common Agricultural Policy]] and the [[United States]]' [[Export Enhancement Program]]. Particularly, the objection came to the double standards between the [[General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade]] (GATT) forcing countries to liberalise their economies, whilst the [[United States]] was granted a waiver for agricultural protection in the 1950s. The Cairns Group's objective is to bring about [[liberalisation]] of global trade in agricultural [[produce]]<!-- Not Products, nor goods-->. In particular, its members aim to abolish [[export subsidies]] and trade-distorting ("[[Agreement on Agriculture|amber box]]") [[domestic support]] measures for agricultural products{{Verify source|date=August 2007}} and seek to improve [[market access]] for exported agricultural goods. The coalition attempts to present a common front in multilateral trade negotiations at the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO), tabling joint proposals and occasionally working with like-minded groups such as the [[G20 developing nations|G20]] group of developing nations. ===Uruguay Round=== The Cairns Group successfully forced agriculture onto the agenda of the [[Uruguay Round]]. This eventually led to the [[Agreement on Agriculture]]. ===Protectionist pressures=== In the ongoing [[Doha Round]] of trade negotiations, they are mainly opposed by WTO members seeking to uphold their high level of agricultural protection on grounds of public policy, such as the [[EU]], [[Japan]], [[Norway]], [[South Korea]], [[Switzerland]] and United States (dubbed the "[[Multifunctionality|multifunctionalists]]"). ==References== {{unreferenced|date=April 2012}} {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://cairnsgroup.org/Pages/default.aspx Cairns Group] * [http://www.cairnsgroupfarmers.org/ Cairns Group Farm Leaders] {{Cairns Group member countries}} [[Category:International trade]] [[Category:Agricultural policy]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Argentina]] [[Category:Agriculture in Argentina]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Australia]] [[Category:Agriculture in Australia]] [[Category:Agriculture in Bolivia]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Bolivia]] {{int-org-stub}} {{international-trade-stub}}
